word.entryDescription: a kind of table, often with drawers, which you write and work at
word.entryExample: There is a desk in my bedroom.

word.entryDescription: ready to do anything to change a very bad situation, without worrying about danger
word.entryExample: The coaches at the side of the pitch are looking frustrated and the fans in the stadium are desperate.

word.entryDescription: without being prevented by; in spite of
word.entryExample: Despite the lack of evidence, many people continue to believe this argument.

word.entryDescription: a sweet food which you usually eat after the main course
word.entryExample: For dessert we'd like an apple, and six bowls of chocolate ice cream.

word.entryDescription: to make a system, government, economy, etc. become less successful or powerful; to make it unstable
word.entryExample: They were trying to destabilise the government.

word.entryDescription: the place that someone or something is travelling to
word.entryExample: Birds cover long distances before they arrive at their destination.

word.entryDescription: to damage something so badly that it stops existing or it cannot be used
word.entryExample: A heavy flow of water can destroy buildings, making them collapse under the weight.

word.entryDescription: damaged so badly that it no longer exists or is no longer usable
word.entryExample: A lot of buildings were completely destroyed after the tsunami.

word.entryDescription: the act of destroying something
word.entryExample: The destruction from the tsunami was absolutely awful.

word.entryDescription: a house that is not connected to another house
word.entryExample: My ideal home would be a detached house in the suburbs of a city.

word.entryDescription: a single feature, fact or item
word.entryExample: Detail is important in the world of fashion.

word.entryDescription: a police officer who examines crimes and catches criminals
word.entryExample: The detectives spent a long time investigating the crime.

word.entryDescription: strongly damaging or destroying something
word.entryExample: He was badly injured in a devastating fire.

word.entryDescription: to become bigger, stronger, or more advanced
word.entryExample: Steve has developed bigger and more powerful rockets that can fly.

word.entryDescription: relating to a country which is relatively poor, relatively unindustrialised or not very advanced economically
word.entryExample: Fairtrade helps to make people aware of the problem of low wages in developing countries.

word.entryDescription: the process of becoming more advanced or the process of putting new buildings on land
word.entryExample: The council says rapid development is at least being properly planned.

word.entryDescription: a machine, tool, object, etc which has been made to do a particular task
word.entryExample: The thing I like most about my device is that it is portable.

word.entryDescription: past simple and past participle form of 'diagnose' – to do tests, examinations, etc. in order to find out what illness a patient has or what causes a fault
word.entryExample: Twelve patients still need to have their condition diagnosed by Doctor Wu.

word.entryDescription: a book in which you write down the events of each day, and your thoughts and feelings
word.entryExample: Mum said I should write a holiday diary.

word.entryDescription: to cut into small square pieces
word.entryExample: Dice the vegetables before putting them in

word.entryDescription: an order or rule that should be obeyed
word.entryExample: She usually follows the dictates of fashion.

word.entryDescription: a book which lists words alphabetically and gives their meanings
word.entryExample: Use a dictionary to label the picture with the words below.

word.entryDescription: to stop living
word.entryExample: Many people die or are injured in road accidents every year.

word.entryDescription: a time when you try to get thinner or healthier by controlling what you eat
word.entryExample: Competitors train tirelessly and follow a strict diet if they want to have a chance of victory.

word.entryDescription: not the same
word.entryExample: You can catch the boat at many different places in the city.

word.entryDescription: not similar to
word.entryExample: How is ethical fashion different from mainstream fashion?

word.entryDescription: not easy
word.entryExample: Skiing is very difficult.

word.entryDescription: careful to work hard and do everything you are required to do; conscientious
word.entryExample: He's a very diligent student.

word.entryDescription: a room where you sit down at a table to eat
word.entryExample: Can we sit in the dining room?

word.entryDescription: the main meal of the day, or a meal you eat in the evening
word.entryExample: What's for dinner, Mum?

word.entryDescription: an animal belonging to a group of reptiles that became extinct millions of years ago
word.entryExample: Dinosaurs are extinct, aren't they?

word.entryDescription: a document which shows you have completed a course or passed an exam
word.entryExample: Now coming back to the subject, what diploma did you get?

word.entryDescription: the person who controls the actors, scenes, etc while making a film
word.entryExample: The director said the actors needed to get ready for the next scene.

word.entryDescription: not clean
word.entryExample: The car's very dirty. I need to wash it.

word.entryDescription: lacking a particular physical or mental ability because of illness, injury, etc
word.entryExample: She thinks it's important for both disabled and non-disabled young people to get access to physical exercise.

word.entryDescription: to not agree
word.entryExample: Do the speakers agree or disagree with each other?

word.entryDescription: unhappy because something you were hoping for or expecting either did not happen or was unsatisfactory
word.entryExample: Maria’s very disappointed because she got a lower exam mark than she was expecting.

word.entryDescription: failing to satisfy your hopes or expectations
word.entryExample: It's disappointing that people can't be more considerate.

word.entryDescription: the feeling of sadness because things did not go the way you expected or hoped
word.entryExample: It's such a disappointment because I really loved the first two series and even bought the DVDs for them, so I could see them again.

word.entryDescription: a place where you can go to dance to pop music
word.entryExample: We have a fitness club that starts at 10 a.m. every day, a daily film at 5 p.m. and disco at 10 p.m.

word.entryDescription: an amount lower than the normal price
word.entryExample: What do you get a discount for in some shops?

word.entryDescription: a condition caused by an infection or an internal problem which affects the normal function of the body; an illness
word.entryExample: Bubonic plague was a disease that was carried by fleas.

word.entryDescription: telling lies, cheating and unable to be trusted; not honest
word.entryExample: James dislikes dishonest people.

word.entryDescription: a machine used to wash the dishes
word.entryExample: They didn't have to do the washing up because Judith had a new dishwasher.

word.entryDescription: to not like
word.entryExample: People think she's nasty because she seems to dislike everyone.

word.entryDescription: (of people) forced to move away from home to another place
word.entryExample: The number of homeless and displaced people emerging from WWII led the Red Cross to offer both emergency and long-term support services to refugees around the world.

word.entryDescription: a glass box, used to show something valuable
word.entryExample: On Sunday 20th March, the guards noticed that the back door of the building and the display case containing the cup had been forced open.

word.entryDescription: an argument or disagreement, often an angry one
word.entryExample: The dispute was settled out of court.

word.entryDescription: not showing consideration for other people's feelings, wishes or rights
word.entryExample: That comment was worse than disrespectful, it was offensive!

word.entryDescription: how far one thing is from another thing
word.entryExample: Birds which travel long distances in search of food migrate.
